disp-quote.p: Teachers serve as socialization agents in society by influencing our attitudes and behaviors as strongly as academic and musical knowledge.

body.p: For years, music teachers have been sharing and introducing students to the musics of diverse cultures. In 1992, Keith Thompson—as the editor of General Music Today—reminded readers “We are truly living and teaching in a global village and we can no longer assume that students share a common experience” (p. 2). He also reminded readers that learning music from other cultures involved “more than donning the costumes of another people and singing a melody from some foreign land” (p. 2). Twenty-one years later, I believe general music teachers have learned to avoid the “cursory nod” approach to world musics and now deliver instruction on diverse musics in a more genuine manner.

Music can convey and capture a culture’s essence. Cultural practices of music can be understood by observing the ways individuals respond to each other and to the music. Froehlich (2007), in discussing the intricacy of interactions in our daily life, terms this complex process webs of interaction. “By emphasizing the interaction and the meanings of these interactions to the individuals, groups, social structures, and institutions, we gain much richer and deeper knowledge that subsequently demonstrates music as a meaningful and relevant educational endeavor” (Abeles & Custodero, 2010, p. 25). Teachers who include information about the people, their traditions, and their arts can engage students and broaden their music repertoire at this richer, deeper level.

Webs of interaction act as socialization agents for students. When introducing new music to students, teachers should strive to convey the relationships between the music and the music makers, recognizing the interactions and the interdependency of one on the other. Teachers play a major socialization role for students (Ballantine, 2001; Levine & Levine, 1996) and through their curriculum choices play a role in the “equality of education” opportunities in the classroom (Coleman, 1990; Kozol, 1991). Kelly (2009, p. 94) identifies the following music teacher characteristics and strategies as playing a role in learning experiences with equal opportunities for all students:

list-item.p: Willingness to work with all students

body.p: Cognizance of the importance of socialization and curricular choices, combined with the skill sets associated with effective teaching, can create equal opportunities for students and promote the inclusion of all musics.

Music enjoyment draws students into your classrooms. Culturally responsive and respectful teachers recognize that communication, expression, teamwork, and repertoire selection can cultivate student interest. Be open to others—be open to all styles of music—be open to change. This “openness” allows you to provide equal opportunities and embrace diverse musics and students in your classroom.
